PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Both operating divisions at the facility have worked to address safety issues as they arise in a continued effort to ensure a safe working environment.  Compliance Audits, PHA studies, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, in addition to routine PSM/RMP Committee Meetings have generated recommendations to improve safety and compliance at the facility.  These include enhancing employee training policies, revising standard operating procedures, improving documentation and recordkeeping, and updating preventative maintenance policies, as well as ammonia equipment repairs.

Kroger Company representatives along with consultants entrenched in risk management for ammonia refrigeration facilities provide guidance and assistance for the facility personnel to ensure outstanding issues are resolved, and that the facility remains in compliance.  The Kroger Riverside facility also plans to improve safety as follows:

  --  Continued involvement of refrigeration and safety personnel in the ongoing development and implementation of the risk management policies.
  --  Participation of key personnel in industry recommended training classes to ensure the facility is aware of evolving industry standards and techniques used to encourage a safety culture at the facility.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  

An emergency planning and response policy has been developed at the Kroger / Ralph’s Grocery Company facility and is maintained by the Maintenance and Safety departments.  It is based on Cal-OSHA’s requirements for Emergency Action Plan (CCR Title 8, Section 3220).  The Emergency Action Plan is detailed in the Emergency Planning & Response section of the PSM/RMP document which is maintained by the Maintenance Manager and the Plant Engineer at the respective operating divisions of the facility.

This program contains procedures detailing how the facility will respond to accidental ammonia releases and other emergencies such as fires, earthquakes, power outages, etc.  This program has been coordinated with the local emergency service agencies including: the City of Riverside Fire Department, and the County of Riverside Department of Environmental Health – Hazardous Materials Management Branch.

The facility’s Emergency Action / Response Policy includes the following elements:

  --  Key Facility Personnel and Responsibilities
  --  Outside Agency Notification Contact Information
  --  Detailed Action Plans for Internal Departments
  --  First Aid Procedures

Safety features utilized for both ammonia refrigeration systems include ammonia leak detectors in the machinery room and other zones where ammonia equipment is located, microprocessor controlled compressors with automatic safety cutouts, ASME certified pressure vessels, and emergency stop controls.  All pressure-rated vessels are equipped with mechanical pressure relief valves that automatically engage in case of a high pressure situation and vent to a water diffusion tank that is available to neutralize high pressure ammonia.  The Kroger / Ralph’s Grocery Company facility, including the ammonia systems, was designed and constructed in accordance with the recognized industry codes and standards, which specifically outline requirements for the design and operation of ammonia refrigeration systems.

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the systems are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to the refrigerant in a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration systems are closed-loop systems without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks / unanticipated ammonia odors are noted and repaired immediately.

Continued safety improvement for the ammonia refrigeration systems is a top priority for Kroger / Ralph’s Grocery Company.  Both operating divisions at the facility (Distribution Center and Creamery) have formed PSM/RMP Committees that meet routinely (typically quarterly) to discuss and review any pending issues with the ammonia refrigeration system and/or the PSM/RMP policies, including any outstanding recommendations made as part of the routine implementation of the programs.

In the event of an ammonia release, the emergency response plan is coordinated with the local emergency planning commission (LEPC) and the local fire department at the City of Riverside Fire Department house.  The ultimate goal for Kroger / Ralph’s Grocery Company’s PSM/RMP plan is to prevent accidental releases of ammonia, injuries / illnesses, and to avoid adverse impacts to the environment.  These programs enable our facility to operate the refrigeration systems safely because they are based on the rules, procedures, and guidelines that govern the ammonia refrigeration systems, as well as the broader ammonia refrigeration industry throughout the country.

For example, all compressors are routinely inspected for oil leaks, pressure and temperature gauge calibrations, vibration analysis, oil pressure, and amp reading for motors;  alignment of compressor motors and bearings, filter changes, vibration readings are routinely performed on compressor motors;  the condensers are inspected weekly (this includes checking and cleaning nozzles and strainers), motors are greased, fans are checked for cracks, and piping is inspected for leaks;  low and intermediate pressure receiver oil pots are drained, pump bearing wear is monitored;  visual inspection for equipment and vessel operating conditions, piping and valves are assessed for leaks, integrity, and other potential abnormalities on daily basis;  pressure relief valves are replaced on a five year frequency.  Ammonia leak detectors, that are designed to alert audible + visual alarms and alerts via the control systems, are calibrated semi-annually.

The evaporators that service the Perishables cold storage warehouse are located on the roof in penthouses that enable easy access for maintenance and inspections of the air units and the valves.

Ammonia is used as the primary refrigerant, which means it is used as a vehicle to move heat from product, cold storage zones, and secondary coolants (glycol) to the outside atmosphere.  When heat is absorbed by the liquid ammonia, it vaporizes (changes phase), and is then compressed by the compressors.  The resulting high pressure ammonia vapor is routed to the condensers, where fans and sprayed water are used to reject latent heat in the ammonia vapor, causing it to condense to a liquid.

Multiple auxiliary systems are in place to support the operational and safety requirements of the both ammonia refrigeration systems including:  ammonia leak detection, auto purgers to remove non-condensible gasses, pressure relief system, and refrigeration control systems.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

To deal with the risks involved with ammonia refrigeration, policies and programs have been developed for the Kroger / Ralph’s Grocery Company facility to limit the risks of an accidental ammonia release and/or minimize the consequences of a significant release, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.

Policies developed for the PSM/RMP programs for both the Distribution Center and the Creamery include employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, pre-startup safety review, standard operating procedures, training, management of change, mechanical integrity, hot work permit, contractor management, and incident investigation. The Maintenance Manager and Plant Engineer have the primary responsibilities for implementation of the PSM and RMP policies aimed at reducing the hazards associated with the ammonia refrigeration systems.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Riverside Distribution Center + Creamery facility has been in operation since the early 1990s.  It is located in the southeastern portion of the city of Riverside, California, just south of the junction of Interstate 215 and Highway 60.  The facility includes a Distribution Center that ships both dry and perishable products to retail locations, and a Creamery facility that manufacturers and packages dairy and other beverage products.  Both of which maintain independent industrial refrigeration systems that utilize anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant.

The Kroger / Ralph’s Grocery Company facility in Riverside, CA manufactures, packages, and distributes food and beverage products and uses the ammonia refrigeration systems (closed-loop processes) for product freezing, cold storage logistics operations, ice making, and process fluid (i.e., glycol) cooling.  The maximum intended inventories of ammonia are approximately 53,000 pounds (Distribution Center Perishables Warehouse), and 17,000 pounds (Creamery).

The accidental release prevention program starts with good operating and manufacturing practices.  All ammonia process equipment, piping, and valves are inspected and maintained on a regular schedule in accordance with manufacturer and industry recommendations.

Refrigeration process equipment at the facility operates continuously based on production and cold storage temperature demands. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Kroger / Ralph’s Grocery Company recognizes the facility’s responsibility in protecting the public, its employees, the environment, equipment, and property.  Kroger / Ralph’s Grocery Company is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration systems at the Kroger / Ralph’s Grocery Company facility in Riverside, California.

It is Kroger / Ralph’s Grocery Company’s policy to ensure that controls are in place to limit the risks of potential ammonia releases.  To accomplish the company’s goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established safety programs that enable facility personnel to: maximize safety performance, reduce risks of handling ammonia and other potentially hazardous substances, and prepare facility personnel to address emergency situations as they might arise.

The Riverside facility draws from several sources and decades of experience + expertise to ensure that the appropriate mitigation measures have been identified and are implemented.  Internal facility personnel, the resources of an extensive and well-established corporate structure, in addition to external risk management consultants all provide guidance to limit the risks of handling ammonia.  The commitment to safety shows in the minimal accident history at the facility.
